titleStmt.title: John Doyle v. William Billings. Writ

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

bibl.title: John Doyle v. William Billings. Writ
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: In The District Court, Of the Second Judicial District of Washington Territory, holding terms at Olympia for the Counties of Mason and Thurston
The People of the Territory of Washington at the motion of John Doyle Ex parte
By the Writ of Habeas Corpus
The Petition of John Doyle to the Honorable John P Hoyt Associate Justice of the Supreme Court and Judge of the Second Judicial District of Washington Territory most respectfully showith
That the said John Doyle is unlawfully restrained of his liberty by being confined in the jail of Thurston County by one William Billings the Keeper of said jail at the City of Olympia

That the cause or pretense for confining your petitioner is as follows. On the 14th day of June 1884 at the County of Mason in Washington Territory one E.F. McReavy appeared before one N J Ross a Justice of the Peace in said Mason County and falsely accused your petitioner with motioning Section 788 of the Code of Washington Territory by putting obstructions upon the track of a railway whereby the lives of persons travelling on said railway were endangered. That the said socalled railway is a wood tramway on which only cars are used. That two cars drawn by steam is used on said road. That said E F McReavy and one John Latham and John McReavy claim to be ownersb of said wood tramway.

That said tramway is a private road way and not a public way, and is solely used by said three persons McReavy, Latham, and McReavy, and by no one else, for the sale and only purpose of hauling logs from a point in the woods a short distance to a point on Hood's Canal in said Mason County, for the sale and exclusive benefit of said three persons named and for no on else.

That near the place where said tramway was his said Hood's Canal, this petitioner owned and owns in fee and is and was lawfully possessed of a house garden and farm, fenced and in continuation on and long before said 14th day of June 1884. That while so peaceably possessed of his said home, the said E F McReavy and divers other persons with force and arms broke and therein down the fences of your petitioner and dug and tore up his grounds fields and gardens and spoiled his grain and erected built and constructed said wood tramway along on and across your petitioners lands and grounds. That the offense for which your petitioner is restrained of his liberty consists of his having fend up his fences and with having tried to prevent the building and running said wood tramway across his said farm garden and grounds.

That the said N J Ross Justice of the Peace aforesaid had no jurisdiction to commit your petitioner under section 788 afore- said. That the offense charged against your petitioner does not constitute a crime.

That this application is based upon the commitment now in the hands of said William Billings, upon the affidavits hereunto annexed and upon the whole record in the cause of the Territory of Washington vs John Doyle your petitioner before said N J Ross Justice as aforesaid.
That a notice of this application has been duly served upon J.C. McFadden the Prosecuting Atty of the Second Judicial District. That bail in his case was fixed at the excessive sum of $3000
Wherefore your petitioner prays that he may be discharged from custody upon his own personal recognizance of bail, or that his bail may be reduced to $100.
Relator
Territory of Washington, County of Thurston } ss

John Doyle being first duly sworn, on oath, says: That he is the Relator named in the above entitled action; that he has heard the foregoing petition read, knows the contents thererof, and believes the same to be true; that he makes this affidavit because
John Doyle
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 30th day of June 1884. D P Ballard Notary Public for Washington Territory.
No. Dist. Court at Olympia
Ty of Washington John Doyle Relator Ex parte
Habeas Corpus
Received and Filed Jul 1 1884 R.G. O'Bruin Clerk
Ballard and McFadden Attorneys for
Notice of application for writ is hereby waived. Olympia Jul 30 1884
J C McFadden Pros atty
